newsitem.title: UK: British police chief warns of "dangerous months".
newsitem.headline: British police chief warns of "dangerous months".

text.p: A police chief warned on Tuesday that Britain faced "dangerous months" in which Irish guerrillas could mount major attacks on key targets on the mainland.

David Veness, assistant commissioner of the Metropolitan Police, was commenting on newspaper reports that IRA guerrillas could be planning a spectacular strike before Christmas, possibly in revenge for the killing by police last month of one of their activists.
"I regret that the threat we confront is likely to be in the long term and looking at the period ahead, we are entering dangerous months," Veness told ITN television in a rare interview.
The Irish Republican Army broke a 17-month truce in February with a series of bombings in Britain, including a blast in June in the northern city of Manchester which injured 200 people.
Earlier this month the IRA planted a bomb inside British army headquarters in Northern Ireland, killing one soldier.
Northern Ireland's chief police officer Sir Hugh Annesley warned in an interview published on Monday that IRA guerrillas would attempt further bomb attacks before laying down their arms again.
Police were reported to have stepped up security round political and military targets ahead of the ceremonial opening of parliament in London on Wednesday.
A spokeswoman at London's Scotland Yard police headquarters said: "There is a continuing campaign of violence by terrorist criminals and we are not being complacent about it."
A spokeswoman urged Britons to be alert and encouraged people to call its anti-terrorist hotline to report any suspicions.
The threat of another IRA attack comes despite some notable successes against the guerrillas, who seek an end to British rule of Northern Ireland.

Last month police seized 100 tonnes of explosives and bomb-making equipment during raids in London which resulted in charges against four people. A fifth man, whom the IRA said later was one of its activists, was shot dead during the raids.
London and Dublin have excluded Sinn Fein, the IRA's political wing, from multi-party peace talks on Northern Ireland, saying the IRA must first end its war against British rule of the province.
